case_name: Income Tax Department v. Owners of steamship El Madina

facts.text: The respondents were the owners of a steamship called El Madina.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were the owners of a steamship called El Madina. That was requisitioned by the Government during the last world war, and was lost by enemy action on 16 March, 1944.

facts.text: The steamship El Madina was requisitioned by the Government during the last world war.

anchor.surface_text: That was requisitioned by the Government during the last world war, and was lost by enemy action on 16 March, 1944. As compensation therefore, the Government paid the respondents Rs. 20,00,000 on 17 July, 1944,

facts.text: The steamship El Madina was lost by enemy action on 16 March 1944.

anchor.surface_text: and was lost by enemy action on 16 March, 1944. As compensation therefore, the Government paid the respondents Rs. 20,00,000 on 17 July, 1944, Rs. 23,00,000 on December 22, 1944, and Rs. 33,333 on 10 August, 1946.

facts.text: Government paid respondents Rs. 20,00,000 on 17 July 1944 as compensation.

anchor.surface_text: As compensation therefore, the Government paid the respondents Rs. 20,00,000 on 17 July, 1944, Rs. 23,00,000 on December 22, 1944, and Rs. 33,333 on 10 August, 1946. The original cost of the ship was Rs. 24,95,016

facts.text: Government paid respondents Rs. 23,00,000 on December 22 1944 as compensation.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 23,00,000 on December 22, 1944, and Rs. 33,333 on 10 August, 1946. The original cost of the ship was Rs. 24,95,016 and its written down value at the commencement of the year of account was Rs. 15,68,484.

facts.text: Original cost of the ship was Rs. 24,95,016.

anchor.surface_text: The original cost of the ship was Rs. 24,95,016 and its written down value at the commencement of the year of account was Rs. 15,68,484. The difference between the cost price and the written-down value, viz., Rs. 9,26,532,

facts.text: Written down value at commencement of year of account was Rs. 15,68,484.

anchor.surface_text: and its written down value at the commencement of the year of account was Rs. 15,68,484. The difference between the cost price and the written-down value, viz., Rs. 9,26,532, represents the deductions which had been allowed year after year on account of depreciation.

facts.text: Difference between cost price and written down value was Rs. 9,26,532 representing depreciation deductions.

anchor.surface_text: The difference between the cost price and the written-down value, viz., Rs. 9,26,532, represents the deductions which had been allowed year after year on account of depreciation. As the total compensation received exceeded the cost price,

facts.text: Total compensation exceeded cost price, recouping depreciation deductions.

anchor.surface_text: As the total compensation received exceeded the cost price, the respondents have recouped themselves all the amounts deducted for depreciation. On these facts, the point in controversy between the respondents and the Department is whether the amount of Rs. 9,26,532

facts.text: Dispute: whether Rs. 9,26,532 liable to be included in total income for 1946-47.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, the point in controversy between the respondents and the Department is whether the amount of Rs. 9,26,532 is liable to be included in the total income of the company for the year of assessment which is 1946-47.

facts.text: It is not disputed that Rs. 9,26,532 would be profits liable to tax under proviso if it applies.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed by the respondents that the sum of Rs. 9,26,532 would be profits liable to be taxed under this proviso, if it applies.

anchor.surface_text: Equally it is not disputed by the appellant that apart from this proviso the amount in question could only be regarded as capital receipt, not liable to be taxed.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal order dated July 15 1953 held amount liable for 1946-47.

facts.text: Respondent filed application under section 66(1) to Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then filed an application before the Tribunal, under section 66(1) of the Act, requiring certain questions to be referred to the court,

facts.text: Tribunal referred question by order dated February 9 1954.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated February 9, 1954, the Tribunal referred the following question for the opinion of the court: Whether the sum of Rs. 9,26,532 was properly included in the assessee company's total income computed for the assessment year 1946-47 ?

facts.text: Reference heard by Bombay High Court bench of Chagla CJ and Tendolkar J.

facts.text: Bombay HC held proviso not retrospective, answered question negative.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits they held that as the proviso was not retrospective in its operation, the amount in question was not liable to be included in the taxable income and answered the question in the negative.

facts.text: Present appeal by special leave against Bombay HC decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reconciling conflicting High Court views through textual analysis of s.66 provisions, advisory jurisdiction nature, and prior SC precedents; outlines four scenarios where questions arise out of Tribunal order.

holdings.text: In the result, we are of opinion that the question of the applicability of the proviso is really implicit, as was held by Chagla, C.J., in the question which was referred, and, therefore, it was one which the court had to answer.
